data.text: Saddle Bags with a Rack versus Seat Bags: Difference?

Hey everyone, just a few questions: Is there a benefit to having a rear rack with saddle bags over one of those seat packs (sorry, I don't know what the term is, but the bags that hang off the rear of the seat), or vice versa? I'm planning a pretty long trip all over my state (WA), but still need to get bags. I plan on going as minimal as possible. 1. What is your opinion? Saddle bags with the rack, or the seat bag? 2. Which tends to cost less? 3. Any good recommendations for either? I do plan on doing my own research on prices and everything, just wanted to get opinions of those who have experienced one or the other.
A rack will take more capacity & weight
data.author: Ashley Burton

data.text: Panniers (the “saddle bags”) have more volume for about the same cost as a seat bag (the bags that hand off the saddle). Panniers are also easier to pack and more useful. It’s easier to pack and organize panniers because of their shape. There are caveats, however. If you are planning a trip that involves rugged off-road travel, a seat bag is a better choice because it attaches to the bike more strongly. Bottom line: if you plan a trip on rough roads and backcountry, bikepacking bags (you’ll need more than just the seat bag). If you plan on riding smooth roads, go with panniers.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Just my opinion but I prefer a rear rack. They are light and reasonable cheap ($50) - you can put a small roll on it or you can load it up. Either way it won't flop around and will be cheaper than a seat bag. I like the versatility. I see that seatbag riders are typically trying to minimize sway and even then some of the "hacks" are stiffeners...kinda like a rack LOL.
data.author: Kent Robinson

data.text: I have both and planning to use both on the next trip. I use the saddle bag for almost every ride as it also works as a mudguard and it is more aerodynamic than the panniers (since it is right behind you), allowing me to keep my spares and maybe some food for a 1 day ride. On a trip, my seatbag (which costed about 70 euro)can hold the sleeping bag, pad, and pillow, and some small things. I decided to add the panniers because I need more space for a longer trip

It's called a rack and pannier system. If your carrying a bunch of stuff it's great. It's also heavier and more difficult on single-track in the woods. Seat bag is cheaper overall and great in minimalist trips. Way lighter and a good one packed well can be great. The drawback is you can't fully use your dropper and they can sway or sag if packed, attached, or designed poorly. I personally like something like the swift industry Zeitgeist bag. data.text: Ok, I haven’t used a seat bag per se, but I have attached a backpack in a similar spot. I preferred panniers. The weight was lower and it was easier for me, and I loved that they were more spacious - I didn’t need all the space, but it’s easier to pack and use on the way when you have some extra room. When I attached a backpack on top of the seat - so the weight distribution was similar as it would be with a seat bag - it was a bit harder for me to balance the bike. I might just be a shitty biker, but PERSONALLY, just based on how the two options distribute weight, I will always choose panniers.

data.author: Alex Helling

data.text: As someone mentioned, seat packs are better for off-road riding, keeping everything up higher provides more clearance if you're going through brush, rocks etc. Panniers can get caught on all this. I prefer to have everything up higher but I've leaned to pack pretty light. Panniers, having stuff lower provides a bit of a sturdier ride. Also keep in mind, you want to try and distribute weight evenly between front and back. You don't want heavy, loaded panniers in the back with nothing up front. Really depends on the kind of riding you're doing - mostly road riding, I'd get a pannier set up. Off road, I'd look at saddle/handlebar bags. Also, just google "touring vs bikepacking" - lots of info out there on this.
data.author: Rob Peters

data.text: I prefer using a rack & panniers, & I find them far easier to pack up each morning than a seat pack. Also easier to get something out during the day, as I put things I may need, like a rain jacket or lunch in the top of each pannier. For shorter, lightweight trips, I use smaller panniers. All that said, I don’t do technical mountain bike trails, which others say panniers are not suitable for, but the panniers have been fine on rails to trails & trails that are somewhat rougher than that (like some of the old, steep, I maintained logging roads near where I live).
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: Thanks for all the answers and opinions! My trip involves off road, but its mainly rail trail until I get over the Cascades and into the metro area, after that a lot of it is either road or gravel. This trip (assuming I routed it correctly) is all rated for gravel, so I don't believe I'll be doing any serious off the smoother trail type riding. At the moment it seems based on all of your experiences and recommendations that a rack and panniers (I thought that's what it was called, but I wasn't for sure!) are what I will go with. I don't plan on bring a lot, but maybe a little more than a seat bag would hold. I also plan on getting one of the smaller frame bags that only takes up the top half of the gap so I can carry extra water, and sleeping bag will probably go up front. Thanks again, everyone!

So overall, having toured both…I way prefer rack and pannier. The space, the on the go access and ease of taking off/on at night/morning when camping and exhausted is a million miles easier. That said the hook system most panniers have will rattle on rail trail if it is gravel.
